pageData.text: In this investigation, students will observe the effects of two different antibacterial drugs on two common bacterial species, one Gram-positive and one Gram-negative. Students will measure zones of inhibition around paper disks containing each of these antibacterial drugs that have been incubated with each bacterial species. They will then compare the measurements to standard values to determine the effectiveness of each drug against the two types of bacteria.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Antibiotic</button>-resistant bacteria are a growing problem around the world. Because bacteria evolve rapidly, and antibiotics are so widely used, even newly discovered antibiotics can quickly become obsolete if not used properly. Scientists are constantly trying to find new classes of antibiotics that use novel mechanisms, thus decreasing the chances of bacterial resistance. To develop new antibiotics, potential antibiotic molecules are identified, then tested for efficacy and safety in humans. This process can be expensive and take years to complete.

Some scientists are turning to AI systems and machine learning to cut down on the time it takes to identify potential molecules to be tested<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. These systems comb massive databases of molecules and run simulations to determine if any are suitable candidates for further study. This approach has the potential to not only help patients sooner, but also facilitate development of more targeted therapies for specific bacterial strains. This technology can also be helpful in identifying antibiotics with mechanisms that scientists have not yet considered. Such new classes of antibiotics could then treat infections caused by bacteria with resistance to existing treatments.

pageData.text: Some microorganisms, particularly soil-dwelling fungi and bacteria, naturally produce <button class='glossary-text'>antimicrobial</button> compounds called <button class='glossary-text'>antibiotics</button>. These antibiotics help give such organisms an advantage against other microbes because the compounds allow them to eliminate competing microbes in their habitat.

These natural antibiotic effects were first documented in 1928 by Dr. Alexander Fleming, a Scottish scientist who had been attempting to identify agents that acted against Staphylococcus bacteria. He observed that a type of mold (Penicillium) had contaminated a plate culture of Staphylococcus bacteria and that bacteria close to the mold had been killed. Through further research, he discovered that Penicillium produced a substance that inhibited growth of the bacteria. Subsequently, penicillin was identified and used as the first antibiotic to treat bacterial infections. Over time, researchers discovered ways to modify the structure of penicillin in the laboratory, and as a result, several forms of penicillin with varying effectiveness exist today. Antibiotics and other antimicrobial drugs are now commonly prescribed to treat microbial infections. Such drugs effectively inhibit growth of certain microbes, but different types of microbes may respond differently to the same drug.

To date, hundreds of antibiotics have been isolated from bacteria and fungi, and many compounds with the ability to kill microbes or inhibit their growth have been created in the laboratory. The term “antibiotic” commonly refers to any antimicrobial drug, particularly if the drug is directed against a bacterial infection. However, a compound is only properly called an antibiotic if, like penicillin, it is derived from a natural source. Any agents that kill or inhibit microbes, including antibiotics and compounds synthesized in a laboratory, are called antimicrobials. Antimicrobials may be (affecting one or a few microbial types) or (affecting a wide variety of microbes). They effectively treat infections caused by certain bacteria, fungi, protozoans, and some viruses. Typically, antimicrobials are grouped according to the class of microbes they inhibit, including antiviral, antibacterial, antifungal, and antiprotozoal drugs. Antimicrobials are also used to prohibit food spoilage, treat certain diseases in plants, and prevent unwanted microbial growth in various tissues and cultures used for scientific investigations.

Only a small percentage of known are useful medicines, as many compounds are toxic to the host (infected individual) or are not sufficiently species-specific and could harm helpful microbes. In fact, none of the antimicrobial drugs currently used in modern medicine actually meet the criteria of an ideal antimicrobial drug, which would have a broad spectrum of activity, be nontoxic (no side effects on the host), extremely stable (i.e., unaffected by heat, enzymes, etc.), have long-lasting effects, and not destroy the vital microbial population normally inhabiting the host.An organism’s susceptibility to antimicrobials varies considerably. antimicrobials limit growth and reproduction, while drugs destroy the microbe. If the effect is specific to a particular type of microbe, such as bacteria or fungi, the drug may be described as bacteriostatic or bactericidal, fungistatic or fungicidal, etc.Antimicrobial drugs have five modes of action against their targets (see Figure 1):
  1. Inhibition of protein synthesis (e.g., tetracycline)
  2. Inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis (e.g., actinomycin)
  3. Inhibition of cell wall synthesis (e.g., penicillins)
  4. Disruption of cell membrane function (e.g., novobiocin)
  5. Blockage of specific biochemical pathways, thus inhibiting metabolism (e.g., sulfonamides)

pageData.altText: Figure 1: List of the five mechanisms of antimicrobial drug action: inhibition of protein synthesis, inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis, inhibition of cell wall synthesis, disruption of cell membrane function, and block pathways and inhibit metabolism; all superimposed over a diagram of a typical bacterial cell.

pageData.text: are often effective in quite small concentrations. Various combinations of antimicrobials may be used against a pathogen (disease-causing microbe) that is not affected by a single drug. Multiple drugs may also be used to treat infections caused by more than one type of microbe. Bacteria commonly have varying degrees of sensitivity to antibacterial drugs, often due to characteristics of their cell wall. Bacteria are grouped into one of two categories based on their reaction to the Gram stain test, which differs based on the composition of their cell wall (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram depicting the cytoplasmic membrane and cell wall structures of Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria. Key features shown are the relatively greater amount of periplasmic space in the Gram-negative cell, much greater amount of peptidoglycan in the Gram-positive, and presence of an outer membrane in the Gram-positive. The Gram-negative bacterial cell also has lipopolysaccharide and porins associated with the outer membrane.

pageData.text: All bacterial cells have a cytoplasmic membrane consisting mainly of phospholipid molecules and proteins that selectively separates the cytoplasm within the cell from the external environment. Most bacteria also have a cell wall that lies outside the cytoplasmic membrane. The cell wall allows the bacterial cell to maintain a definite shape and resist changes in osmotic pressure. It also influences how the bacterium reacts with dyes that can be added to bacteria on a slide to improve viewing with a microscope, and how the bacterium is affected by antibacterial drugs.Just outside the cytoplasmic membrane is the periplasmic space, which contains a gelatinous material called periplasm. The periplasmic space is relatively large in Gram-negative bacteria, and much smaller in Gram-positive bacteria.

In Gram-positive bacteria, numerous layers of a polymer called peptidoglycan lie outside the periplasmic space. The thick peptidoglycan tends to trap and retain crystal violet dye, used in the Gram stain procedure, and appear purple when viewed with a microscope. Gram-negative bacteria have just a few layers of peptidoglycan located in the periplasmic space, so they easily lose crystal violet dye during the Gram stain procedure. They appear red or pink after the Gram stain procedure. Gram-negative bacteria also have an outer membrane that Gram-positive bacteria lack, which is often linked to peptidoglycan by lipoproteins. The membrane includes specialized proteins called porins, water-filled channels that permit the diffusion of ions and small water-soluble molecules. The external face of the outer membrane includes lipopolysaccharide molecules, which trigger strong immune responses in humans and animals.

Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria vary in their degree of sensitivity to antibacterial drugs. Gram-negative bacteria tend to be less sensitive to antibacterial drugs in general because many antibacterial compounds cannot pass through the outer membrane. Furthermore, less peptidoglycan is present in their cell wall, which is a favored target of many drugs. Thus, fewer antibacterial drugs currently exist to effectively combat Gram-negative bacterial infections compared to Gram-positive infections.

In recent years, scientists have become concerned with the increasing number of bacterial strains that have become resistant to traditional antibacterial drugs. For example, MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is a bacterial strain that has become resistant to treatment with a form of penicillin called methicillin. Staphylococcus aureus, or “staph,” is a common bacterium that lives on the skin. When entering the bloodstream, staph bacteria can cause a life-threatening infection. Doctors typically prescribe an antibacterial drug to kill Staphylococcus, and the symptoms of the infection are relieved as the bacteria die. In response to the over-administration of antibacterial drugs, however, resistant staphylococcal bacteria have evolved. As a result, methicillin and similar antibacterial drugs no longer have significant effects against many strains of Staphylococcus aureus.

Both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria can become resistant to antibacterial drugs in several ways. Bacterial genes are present on the bacterial chromosome and on plasmids (small, extra-chromosomal pieces of DNA). Bacteria can develop resistance to a particular drug through <button class='glossary-text'>mutations</button> (heritable changes) in genes they already carry. In addition, bacteria can obtain foreign genes coding for traits that confer antibacterial drug resistance during many normal processes of gene exchange (e.g., conjugation, transduction, and transformation) with other microbes.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: The four major categories of antibacterial drug resistance strategies in bacteria: cellular impermeability, modification of the drug target, pumping out the drug, and drug inactivation. All are superimposed over a diagram of a typical bacterial cell.

pageData.text:
Resistance adaptations may vary among bacteria, but the four major categories are depicted in Figure 3. They include:
  1. Impermeability due to modified cell wall or membrane structures (usually proteins) that prevent and other antibacterial drugs from permeating the cell
  2. Modification of the drug target, such as an enzyme responsible for a key metabolic process in the bacterium
  3. Pumping out, via bacterial membrane proteins that actively transport the drug out of the cell
  4. Inactivation of the drug by either degradation or chemical modification

pageData.text: The rate of evolution of antibacterial drug resistance in pathogenic bacteria has accelerated as the administration of such drugs has become more common. In the presence of an or other antibacterial drug, any bacterium already resistant to that drug is more likely to survive and multiply than those that are susceptible. Therefore, the resistant bacterium’s progeny will come to dominate the population, and the chance of resistant bacteria multiplying increases every time antibacterial drugs are used (see Figure 4). Because of the rapid life cycle and resulting population growth of bacteria, antibacterial drug resistance has been observed to evolve in some bacteria, like Staphylococcus strains, in fewer than 10 years.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the outcome of using an antibiotic drug to kill only the most susceptible bacteria, allowing the population of resistant bacteria to increase.

pageData.text: When bacteria become resistant to a particular drug, scientists and doctors must identify another drug to which the bacteria are susceptible, if one is available. To identify such a drug, an antibacterial susceptibility test of the bacteria in question must be conducted.

The increasing prevalence of <button class='glossary-text'>antimicrobial</button> resistance has prompted numerous debates regarding the proper use of these drugs, including questioning their agricultural use in healthy animals. In the United States, approximately 60% of antibacterial drugs administered are used in agriculture. Medical professionals now advocate prescribing individuals antibacterial drugs only for bacterial infections, not viral infections that will not be affected by them. Patients given antibacterial drugs are instructed to take the prescribed dosage for the full duration of the treatment. A full course of the drug is usually capable of clearing an infection, but a partial treatment (i.e., too low a dosage and/or too short a treatment duration) is more likely to allow resistance to develop.

Medical laboratories commonly use a classic disk diffusion technique called the to determine antibacterial drug susceptibility. A pure culture of bacteria is isolated from an infected person and spread evenly onto an agar plate. Disks containing different antibacterial drugs are gently placed on the surface of the agar and then incubated with the bacteria (see Figure 5).

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Photo of a large Petri dish containing agar with bacterial growth occurring thickly and evenly across the surface. Eight antibacterial drug disks are evenly spaced on the surface of the agar; some are surrounded by circular areas of clearing, others are not.

pageData.text: After incubation, areas of clearing around the disks that indicate prevented growth of the bacteria, or (see Figure 6), are measured and analyzed using susceptibility reference tables.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Close-up photo of an antibacterial drug disk on the surface of agar in a Petri dish. There is a sharply-defined, circular clear area surrounding the disk.

pageData.text: The disk technique used in this investigation is one of the methods employed to determine the antibacterial activity of a potential drug treatment. A <button class='glossary-text'>zone of inhibition</button> indicates the potency of the drug’s activity against a specific bacterial strain. On the basis of this test, one can determine if the bacteria are susceptible, intermediately susceptible, or resistant to the various antibacterial drugs tested.

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a normal inhabitant of the colon of warm-blooded animals and is a Gram-negative bacterium. Although E. coli is normally nonpathogenic, some strains are implicated in urinary tract infections, food poisoning, diarrheal infections of newborn humans, and scours, a diarrheal infection of newborn calves, pigs, and lambs.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (S. epidermidis) is a normal inhabitant of the skin and mucous membranes of humans and other mammals. S. epidermidis is a Gram-positive bacterium. Unlike closely-related S. aureus, it is generally nonpathogenic. However, S. epidermidis can cause infections in individuals with weakened immune defenses, especially if they have catheters or similar implanted devices that allow S. epidermidis to invade the individual’s bloodstream.

The two antibacterial drugs you will use in this investigation are bacitracin and tetracycline. Each drug has a different mode of action. Like penicillins, bacitracin targets the bacterial cell wall by interfering with the synthesis of peptidoglycan. Bacitracin is a true because it is produced by a strain of the bacterium Bacillus subtilis. Like most cell wall inhibitors, bacitracin is somewhat more effective against Gram-positive bacteria because their cell walls contain more peptidoglycan, and the cells have no outer membrane to block the drug. Bacitracin is bactericidal but too toxic to humans for use internally. However, it is commonly applied topically, either by itself or in combination with other antibacterial drugs.

Tetracycline is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding to bacterial ribosomes and blocking incoming tRNAs that carry amino acids, the building blocks of proteins. It is a drug, effective against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, many of which are resistant to other antibacterial drugs. Tetracycline is also a true antibiotic, produced by members of the bacterial genus Streptomyces. Chemically modified forms of tetracycline are now produced in the laboratory with improved solubility and absorption compared to the original compound.

In this investigation, you will perform a Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test to determine if bacitracin and tetracycline are effective in inhibiting the growth of E. coli and S. epidermidis. For the sake of comparison, you will also place control disks (sterile paper disks containing no drugs) on the surface of the agar.

Incubate the inoculated broth tubes upright in the rack with their caps slightly loose. Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster around 37° C (99° F).

Allow between 1 and 3 days of incubation for the broths to become turbid (cloudy). The length of time required for growth depends on the ambient temperature. Do not proceed until both cultures are growing well.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Note: If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid. You can jostle to the tube gently to see if the growth at the bottom of the tube swirls. If you see a good swirl of growth at the bottom then your culture should be ready to proceed to the next step.
Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–5.

Obtain two nutrient agar plates. Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the outside of the bottom half of each dish with the date. Label one plate “E. coli ” and the other “S. epidermidis.”

Obtain the drug and control disks from the Kirby-Bauer investigation set. Do not remove any of them from their packaging until you are ready to place each disk on the surface of the inoculated agar. The packaging keeps the disks sterile.

In Activity 1, you will test the susceptibility of two strains of bacteria to bacitracin and tetracycline using the . You will measure the zones of inhibition on the plate after 48 hours of incubation.
Before proceeding, view the following video:

pageData.desc: Kirby-Bauer and Lysozyme Inoculation and Disk Application

pageData.text: Mix the E. coli broth culture well by tightly capping the tube and tapping it or rolling it gently between your hands. Then, use a sterile swab to obtain broth from the tube.

Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid.

Note: Part of correct aseptic technique is avoiding excessive removal of the lid from a Petri dish. Open the lid just enough to insert and move the swab, and use the lid as a shield to keep dust off of the agar surface. Close the lid as soon as you are finished.
Inoculate the plate labeled “E. coli ” by gently pulling the swab back and forth across the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern.

Turn the plate approximately 90°, and, without dipping the swab back into the E. coli culture tube, pull the swab again over the entire surface of the agar in a very tight zigzag pattern. Try not to miss any of the agar surface.
Repeat Step 4 two more times until you have swabbed the entire surface of the agar four times. Place the swab in the disposal jar.
Let the E. coli plate sit with the lid on and the agar side facing up.

Dip your forceps into the disposal jar of isopropyl alcohol, tapping them gently on the rim of the jar to remove excess alcohol. Let the tip of the forceps point downward to avoid alcohol dripping on your hand. Light the remaining alcohol on the forceps with the candle, and allow it to burn off while holding it away from your body. Wait at least 15–20 seconds for the forceps to cool. Do not set the forceps down to wait for them to cool, or they will become contaminated.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
Figure 7: Diagram of a Petri dish showing how the three disks should be spaced at equal distances from one another.

pageData.text: Using the forceps, obtain a control disk (a blank paper disk). Open the lid of the E. coli plate slightly and place the disk gently on the surface of the agar, referring to Figure 7 for this and subsequent disk placements.

Press on the disk very carefully with the forceps to make sure it is evenly seated. Do not press the disk below the surface of the agar or break the surface of the agar. Replace the lid of the E. coli plate immediately.
Dip the forceps into the alcohol and sterilize them again with flame as described in Step 7.
Repeat Steps 8–10 with the bacitracin and tetracycline disks.
Invert the E. coli plate (turn it upside-down) and set it aside for incubation.
Repeat Steps 2–12 above, using the S. epidermidis broth culture and agar plate.
Clean your work area as directed in Disposal and Cleanup.
After approximately 48 hours of incubation, examine your plates with the lids on. Do not remove the lids of the Petri dishes during any observations, as this may result in contamination.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After 48 hours, the surface of the agar in both plates should be completely covered with bacterial growth, except for clear zones of inhibition surrounding some of the drug disks. This type of continuous bacterial growth is referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>confluent</button>.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take pictures of the plates. Avoid use of the flash, which will be reflected from the lid and interfere with the image. Do not remove the lids of the Petri dishes to take photos. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your work space. Tilting the plates at a slight angle may improve the image.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to show significant growth.

While keeping each Petri dish closed, measure the diameter (in millimeters) of each with the ruler provided, and record your data in Data Table 1. If necessary, round to the nearest whole millimeter. If the bacterial growth goes right up to the edge of a disk, record the zone of inhibition as “zero (0) mm.”
Referring to Table 1, determine if each bacterium is resistant (R), intermediate (I), or susceptible (S) in its response to each disk, and record these conclusions in Data Table 1.

Note: On occasion, small colonies may be seen growing inside a zone of inhibition. These are clusters of cells that are resistant to the drug. The measurement of a zone of inhibition is not affected by the presence of resistant colonies; however, they should be noted. If the bacterial sample tested were from an actual patient, a drug to which resistant cells are present would not be a desirable choice for treatment, even if the diameter of its zone of inhibition indicates susceptability when compared to a Kirby-Bauer interpretation chart.

To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops and/or swabs), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes, then pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running, and discard the loops in the garbage. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.
Keep your broth cutltures of E. coli and S. epidermidis unless otherwise directed by your instructor.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean with soap and water. PPE should always be worn during the disinfection and cleaning process.

text: Did you notice zones of inhibition around the control disks? Why do you think control disks were included in this investigation?
Did you notice a difference in the effectiveness of the two different antibacterial drugs against the different species of bacteria? Explain your answer.

If a bacterial species is not susceptible to an antibacterial drug at the concentration present in a particular disk, does that necessarily mean the species is completely resistant to the drug? Explain your answer.

Did you notice any colonies (isolated mounds of cells) growing within any of the zones of inhibition? If so, which plate(s) and which drug(s)? What would cause the growth of colonies within a zone of inhibition?

pageData.content: Figure 1. Modes of antimicrobial drug action
pageData.altText: Figure 1: List of the five mechanisms of antimicrobial drug action: inhibition of protein synthesis, inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis, inhibition of cell wall synthesis, disruption of cell membrane function, and block pathways and inhibit metabolism; all superimposed over a diagram of a typical bacterial cell.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacterial cell walls
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram depicting the cytoplasmic membrane and cell wall structures of Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria. Key features shown are the relatively greater amount of periplasmic space in the Gram-negative cell, much greater amount of peptidoglycan in the Gram-positive, and presence of an outer membrane in the Gram-positive. The Gram-negative bacterial cell also has lipopolysaccharide and porins associated with the outer membrane.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Bacterial defense mechanisms against antibiotics
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The four major categories of antibacterial drug resistance strategies in bacteria: cellular impermeability, modification of the drug target, pumping out the drug, and drug inactivation. All are superimposed over a diagram of a typical bacterial cell.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Development of resistant bacterial strains
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the outcome of using an antibiotic drug to kill only the most susceptible bacteria, allowing the population of resistant bacteria to increase.

Figure 5: Photo of a large Petri dish containing agar with bacterial growth occurring thickly and evenly across the surface. Eight antibacterial drug disks are evenly spaced on the surface of the agar; some are surrounded by circular areas of clearing, others are not.
Figure 6: Close-up photo of an antibacterial drug disk on the surface of agar in a Petri dish. There is a sharply-defined, circular clear area surrounding the disk.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, disinfect your work surface and prepare your disposal jars. You will also need to prepare your cultures and label your agar plates. In activity 1, you will inoculate the agar plate with the bacterial culture and then place the control and drug disks on the agar plate. You will repeat the inoculation process for a second bacteria species. Then, you will incubate the test plates at room temperature. Once 48 hours have elapsed, you will measure the zones of inhibition for each disk and determine the drug susceptibility for each bacteria species.

data.title: Antibiotic
data.content: A molecule that inhibits the growth of or kills bacteria

data.title: Antimicrobial
data.content: A molecule that inhibits the growth of or kills microbes; describes antibiotics

data.title: Broad-spectrum
data.content: Describes an antimicrobial agent that affects a wide variety of microbes

data.title: Confluent
data.content: Continuous bacterial growth on a nutrient agar plate

data.title: Kirby-Bauer method
data.content: A laboratory test to determine antibacterial drug susceptibility

data.title: Microbiostatic
data.content: Describes antimicrobials that limit growth and reproduction in microbes

data.title: Mutation
data.content: A heritable change to an organism's genetic code

data.title: Narrow-spectrum
data.content: Describes an antimicrobial agent that only affects one or a few microbial types

data.title: Zone of inhibition
data.content: An area of clearing around antimicrobial disks that indicates prevented growth of the bacteria
